awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Exploring Commercialization Opportunities for New Butyl Nanocomposites
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to expore the commercializtion potential of NSF funded research on nanocomposites based on butyl rubber. 

Nano-composites have potential for numerous versatile applications including coatings, adhesives, pharmaceutical stoppers and medical devices. The rubber nanocomposites are recyclable, eliminating waste during device manufacturing and after use. A similar rubber nanocomposite is used as a coating on drug eluting stents, generating billions of dollars in revenue which further highlights the commercial potential.  

Butyl elastomer, a copolymer of isobutylene with a small amount of isoprene, has outstanding low temperature properties and very high damping, but has very high creep without crosslinking.  It is likely that a blend of poly(styrene-isobutylene-styrene) thermoplastic rubber and butyl elastomer, reinforced with nanofillers such as carbon, silica or iron oxide, would be promising nanocomposites for a broad range of applications.  Future potential improvements include replacing the polymer mix with a single poly(alloocimene-isobutylene-alloocimene) thermoplastic rubber. This project will explore market development and commercialization for various potential blends and applications.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In May of 2016 PolyFiberMatrix for less lethal projectiles was formed, and entered a NSF Innovation Corps aimed at demonstrating the feasibility of transferring fundamental research related to less-lethal ammunition to the marketplace in collaboration with industry During the life of the project, July 2016-July 2017, the team was centered around four main members including: (PI) Judit Puskas, (Entrepreneurial Lead) Andrew McClain, (Mentors) Gabor Kaszas and Susan Louscher. The I-Corps project is the logical extension of PolyFiberMatrix primary objective of providing researchers or businesses with alternative high-performance polymers in support of their needs and as a key step along the path to commercializing the specific polymers for various applications. PolyFiberMatrix (PFM) team participated in the NSF I-Corps program to develop a business model. 103 interviews (75 in person) and over 30 follow-up interviews differentiated potential customer segments from which this team focused on law enforcement officers (police and sheriffs) and prison wardens. Together this team learned how to do a full market assessment connect with leading industry figures, and prepare all necessary information to initiate a Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I proposal that was submitted to NSF on  December 5th, 2016 and received very favorable reviews. The proposal was resubmitted on June 14th, 2017 with addressing the concerns of the reviewers. Rigorous market research revealed potential gross sales over $30 million in the US and over $400 million including international sales per year. The entire global less lethal weapons market is estimated at $2.5 Billion USD. Philpott and Bruzer helped us with the market research, and see a great business opportunity.

In addition to preparing the Phase I proposal, this team has solidified distribution, manufacturing, cost strategies, and revenue stream avenues. In addition to technical aptitude development for the entrepreneurial lead, he has also garnered aptitude in management activities. During the program his ability to connect on a personal level has allowed our partnerships to strengthen in industry figure, Bruzer Less Lethal LLC. They took an advising roll and assisted with market networking and advice on technical performance of the projectile. I-Corps has pushed STEM based business development to the forefront of an American engineering student’s focus. This team continues to seek funding for continued start-up development. 

 


Last Modified: 09/13/2017
Modified by: Judit E Puskas
